notes: The reported AccessViolationException occurs in NonAlertableWin32Lock.EnterCriticalSection, a Windows-only code path using Win32 CRITICAL_SECTION (Kernel32.dll P/Invoke). On macOS/Linux, SkiaSharp uses ReadWriteLock (managed ReaderWriterLockSlim) instead, which has no finalizer and cannot trigger this race condition. Created a standalone repro that deliberately leaks SKObjects to force finalizer cleanup — runs cleanly on macOS as expected since the vulnerable code path is Windows-only. Triage confirms this is a duplicate of #2194, fixed in v2.88.1 by PR #2195 which added null-checks before entering/leaving the CRITICAL_SECTION. The fix is verified present on main (PlatformLock.cs lines 123, 130). Reproducing the actual crash requires Windows.

versionResults.notes: Ran on macOS arm64 — no crash because ReadWriteLock is used instead of NonAlertableWin32Lock. The vulnerable code path (Win32 CRITICAL_SECTION) only exists on Windows.
Ran on macOS arm64 — same as 2.88.0, no crash. Fix was shipped in 2.88.1 regardless.

Built and ran SKObjectTest and finalizer tests from source — all pass. Verified the null-check fix from PR #2195 is present in PlatformLock.cs (lines 123, 130). The crash cannot be triggered on macOS.

blockers: Requires Windows — the crash occurs in NonAlertableWin32Lock.EnterCriticalSection which uses Win32 Kernel32.dll CRITICAL_SECTION P/Invoke. On macOS/Linux, SkiaSharp uses ReadWriteLock (managed ReaderWriterLockSlim) which has no finalizer and cannot trigger this race condition. The vulnerable code path is conditionally compiled with '#if !(__IOS__ || __TVOS__ || __MACOS__ || __MACCATALYST__ || __ANDROID__)' and further gated by 'PlatformConfiguration.IsWindows'.

triageCorrections.corrected: Confirmed Windows-only — code inspection shows NonAlertableWin32Lock is gated by PlatformConfiguration.IsWindows and uses Kernel32.dll P/Invoke. Cannot affect macOS/Linux at all.
